unnormalised: Someone asked me what to do when a delivery guy can't find your address in India. Well, bhai, this is something most of us have faced, haven't we? My usual address listed is "House no. 123/4, Near the big banyan tree, Opp. Sharma General Store, Gandhi Nagar, Bangalore, 560001". Simple, right? WRONG. Apparently, "big banyan tree" and "Sharma General Store" are too vague for our modern delivery logistics.
normalised: Someone asked me what to do when a delivery guy cannot find your address in India. Well, bhai, this is something most of us have faced, have not we? My usual address listed is "House number one hundred twenty three slash four, Near the big banyan tree, Opposite Sharma General Store, Gandhi Nagar, Bangalore, five six zero zero zero one". Simple, right? WRONG. Apparently, "big banyan tree" and "Sharma General Store" are too vague for our modern delivery logistics.

unnormalised: So, here's my pro-tip: make friends with your local chaiwala or the paan shop guy. Seriously. Their address is probably "Near the signal, beside the temple." Delivery folks understand *that*. Or, just give them landmark details like, "3rd left after the SBI ATM, behind the blue building." You might think you're being clear by saying, "Plot no. 7, Sector 10, Gurugram, Haryana, 122001," but unless your sector is the size of a postage stamp, prepare for the dreaded "address not found" call.

unnormalised: And if all else fails, embrace the chaos! Tell the delivery guy, "Just come to Gandhi Nagar, I'll stand outside the Sharma General Store (if it still exists!), near the almost-dead banyan tree. You can't miss me." It's worked for me, like, 90% of the time. Good luck and may your packages arrive safe and sound… eventually.
